{{Infobox Prime Minister | image = Twagiramungu Faustin.jpg | name = Faustin Twagiramungu | order = 6th [[Prime Minister of Rwanda]] | president = [[Pasteur Bizimungu]] | deputy = | term_start = 19 July 1994 | term_end = 28 August 1995<ref name=dict/> | predecessor = [[Jean Kambanda]]| | successor = [[Pierre-Célestin Rwigema]] | birth_date = 14 August 1945 | birth_place = Gishoma commune, [[Cyangugu Province|Cyangugu]] prefecture<ref name=Testimony>{{cite web|url=http://www.rwandadocumentsproject.net/gsdl/collect/mil1docs/archives/HASH01ba/3d6f15e3.dir/doc82617.PDF|title=ICTR Witness statement, Faustin Twagiramungu|date=13 April 2000}}</ref> | nationality = [[Rwanda]]n | spouse = Maria Assumpta Taigga<ref name=Testimony/> | mother = Anizi Nyahizumwami | father = Jean Gishumgu | residence = [[Brussels]], [[Belgium]] | profession = | education = [[McGill University]]<ref name=dict>{{cite book|last1=Twagilimana|first1=Aimable|title=Historical Dictionary of Rwanda|date=2007|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810864269|pages=[https://books.google.no/books?id=nvQlAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA161 161f]}}</ref> | party = Rwandan Dream Initiative | Political party = }} '''Faustin Twagiramungu''' (born 14 August 1945) is a [[Rwanda]]n politician. He was [[Prime Minister]] from 1994 until his resignation in 1995, the first head of government appointed after the [[Rwandan Patriotic Front]] (RPF) captured [[Kigali]]. He then exiled himself to [[Belgium]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Rwandan ex-PM goes home|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/3006622.stm|work=[[BBC News]]|date=20 June 2003}}</ref>
==Biography== Twagiramungu was born on 14 August 1945 in [[Cyangugu Province|Cyangugu]] prefecture. Although [[Hutu]] in origin, Twagiramungu rejects the [[ethnic group|ethnic]] label, preferring to see himself as a Rwandan.<ref>{{cite AV media|people=Gargot, Christophe (Director)|title=D'Arusha à Arusha|trans-title=From Arusha to Arusha|minutes=20|date=2008|url=https://vimeo.com/77431259}}</ref> Twagiramungu speaks [[Kinyarwanda]], [[French language|French]], [[Swahili language|Swahili]] and [[English language|English]].<ref name=Testimony/>
Twagiramungu studied and worked in [[Quebec]], Canada, from 1968 to 1976, during which time he experienced [[Quebec sovereignty movement|Quebec separatism]] and met with [[René Lévesque]].<ref>{{cite book|author-link=Roméo Dallaire|last=Dallaire|first=Roméo A.|date=2003|title=[[Shake Hands with the Devil (book)|Shake Hands with the Devil: The Failure of Humanity in Rwanda]]|location=Toronto|publisher=Random House Canada|isbn=1407098748|pages=[https://books.google.no/books?id=cAzcVWCHZSMC&pg=PA60 60], [https://books.google.no/books?id=cAzcVWCHZSMC&pg=PA132 132]}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Temple-Raston|first1=Dina|authorlink=Dina Temple-Raston|title=Justice on the Grass: Three Rwandan Journalists, Their Trial for War Crimes, and a Nation's Quest for Redemption|date=2005|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=9780743251105|pages=[https://books.google.no/books?id=wK-2Ft9AoX0C&pg=PA57 57f]}}</ref> After returning to Rwanda, he ran a transportation company called Magasins Généraux du Rwanda (MAGERWA).<ref name=dict/>
==Political career== Twagiramungu rose to political prominence after the democratic opening in Rwanda in 1991,<ref name=dict/> as the chairman of a new political party, the [[Republican Democratic Movement]] ({{abbr|MDR|Mouvement Démocratique Républicain}}).<ref name=Testimony/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://rwandadelaguerreaugenocide.univ-paris1.fr/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/From-War-to-Genocide-Box-5.pdf|title=From War to Genocide, Box 5: Political parties and organizations officially registered in 1991|first=André|last=Guichaoua}}</ref> MDR joined the multiparty government set up in April 1992, and a MDR politician, [[Dismas Nsengiyaremye]], became the Prime Minister. However, in July 1993, MDR was split between two factions headed by Nsengiyaremye and Twagiramungu, who both wanted to be the Prime Minister in the anticipated Broad-Based Transitional Government (BBTG), a post which was to be decided prior to the signing of the [[Arusha Accords (Rwanda)|Arusha Accords]]. Twagiramungu's faction was weak, but he succeeded thanks to support from the other political parties.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Guichaoua|first1=André|title=From War to Genocide: Criminal Politics in Rwanda, 1990–1994|date=2015|publisher=University of Wisconsin Pres|isbn=9780299298203|pages=[https://books.google.no/books?id=KseuCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA88 88ff]}}</ref> The Arusha Accords were signed on 4 August 1993, and Twagiramungu was chosen to be the Prime Minister.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.refworld.org/docid/3ae6b4fcc.html|title=Peace Agreement between the Government of the Republic of Rwanda and the Rwandese Patriotic Front|date=4 August 1993|website=refworld.org}}</ref> The BBTG was never installed.
===Prime Minister after the genocide=== In July 1994, Twagiramungu finally became Prime Minister in the Arusha-inspired "Government of National Unity" set up by the RPF after taking power in wake of the [[Rwandan genocide]].<ref>{{cite book|first=Timothy|last=Longman|authorlink=Timothy Longman|page=[https://books.google.no/books?id=83s9j07bS1UC&pg=PA32 32]|chapter=Limitations to Political Reform: The Undemocratic Nature of Transition in Rwanda|editor-last1=Straus|editor-first1=Scott|editor1-link=Scott Straus|editor-last2=Waldorf|editor-first2=Lars|title=Remaking Rwanda: State Building and Human Rights after Mass Violence|date=2011|publisher=The University of Wisconsin Press|isbn=978-0-299-28264-6}}</ref> His appointment was tinged with symbolism for many Rwandans, as he was the son-in-law of [[Grégoire Kayibanda]].<ref>{{cite news|title=The Three Victors Who Will Lead Rwanda|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/07/20/world/the-three-victors-who-will-lead-rwanda.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=20 July 1994}}</ref> After taking office, Twagiramungu was faced with the vexing problem of [[Human rights in Rwanda|human rights]] abuses by the RPF. Like interior minister [[Seth Sendashonga]], he believed there had to be a certain amount of tolerance, but was worried when there seemed to be no end in sight. According to the historian [[Gérard Prunier]] who has discussed the issue with Twagiramungu at length, "The Hutu ministers were so conscious of the potential catastrophe their eventual resignations could cause that they swallowed it all in the name of national unity. Until the [[Kibeho massacre|Kibeho slaughter]] pushed them over the brink."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Prunier|first1=Gérard|authorlink=Gérard Prunier|title=Africa's World War: Congo, the Rwandan Genocide, and the Making of a Continental Catastrophe|date=2009|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199705832|pages=[https://books.google.no/books?id=kp93kUfdhC0C&pg=PA17 17f]}}</ref> The tension within the administration came to a head when Twagiramungu called for an "extraordinary council of ministers on security matters" which met on 23 August 1995 and ended two days later when [[Paul Kagame]]—the ''de facto'' leader of Rwanda and the RPF—made a sardonic comment and left the room.<ref name=resign/> On 28 August, Twagiramungu decided to resign, and four other ministers were fired the next day, including Sendashonga.<ref name=resign>{{cite book|last1=Prunier|first1=Gérard|authorlink=Gérard Prunier|title=Africa's World War: Congo, the Rwandan Genocide, and the Making of a Continental Catastrophe|date=2009|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199705832|pages=[https://books.google.no/books?id=kp93kUfdhC0C&pg=PA45 45f]|language=en}}</ref> Twagiramungu was put under house arrest, but managed to leave the country by the end of the year.<ref name=resign/>
===Opposition in exile=== In [[Brussels]] in March 1996, Twagiramungu and Sendashonga set up an exiled opposition party called the Democratic Forces for Resistance ({{abbr|FRD|Forces de Résistance pour la Démocratie}}).<ref>{{cite book|last1=Reyntjens|first1=Filip|title=Political Governance in Post-Genocide Rwanda|date=2013|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9781107043558|page=[https://books.google.no/books?id=dX4LAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA22 22]}}</ref> FRD was officially launched in April 1997.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Prunier|first1=Gérard|authorlink=Gérard Prunier|title=Africa's World War: Congo, the Rwandan Genocide, and the Making of a Continental Catastrophe|date=2009|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199705832|pages=[https://books.google.no/books?id=kp93kUfdhC0C&pg=PA365 365]|language=en}}</ref> On 16 May 1998, Sendashonga, who had survived an earlier attempt on his life, was assassinated in [[Nairobi]]. Twagiramungu denounced the murder and accused the Rwandan government of culpability.<ref>{{cite news|title=IRIN Update No. 418 for Central and Eastern Africa|url=https://reliefweb.int/report/burundi/irin-update-no-418-central-and-eastern-africa|work=[[IRIN]]|publisher=[[ReliefWeb]]|date=18 May 1998|language=en}}</ref> In 2001, a [[Kenya]]n court found that the murder was political and blamed the Rwandan government.<ref>{{cite news|title=Court acquits Sendashonga accused|url=https://www.irinnews.org/report/21889/rwanda-court-acquits-sendashonga-accused|work=[[IRIN]]|date=31 May 2001|language=en}}</ref>
In 1998, FRD invited four other exiled movements ([[Republican Rally for Democracy in Rwanda|RDR]], {{abbr|GID|Initiative Group for Dialogue}}, {{abbr|RNLM|Rwandan National Liberation Movement}} and [[Rwandese National Union|UNAR]]) to form the Union of Rwandan Democratic Forces ({{abbr|UFDR|Union des Forces Démocratiques Rwandaises}}), which wanted to press for a new power-sharing agreement along the lines of the Arusha Accords,<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.larouchepub.com/eiw/public/1998/eirv25n42-19981023/eirv25n42-19981023_042-unity_conference_challenges_sile.pdf|journal=[[Executive Intelligence Review]]|volume=25|number=42|title=Unity conference challenges silence on Rwanda|first=Linda|last=de Hoyos|date=23 October 1998}}</ref> and Twagiramungu was slated to be its president from 1998 to 2002.<ref name=Rafti/> RNLM and UNAR were both old monarchist parties, seen to represent [[Tutsi]] interests, but they soon abandoned the alliance.<ref name=Rafti>{{cite web|url=https://www.uantwerpen.be/images/uantwerpen/container2143/files/Publications/DP/2004/01-rafti.pdf|first=Marina|last=Rafti|title=The Rwandan Political Opposition In Exile: A Valid Interlocutor Vis-à-vis Kigali?|work=Institute of Development Policy and Management, [[University of Antwerp]]|pages=13f|date=April 2004}}</ref> As president of UFDR, Twagiramungu reportedly worked as if he was alone, creating "a party within a party", and was distanced even from the majority of his own party, the FRD.<ref name=partywithin>{{cite web|url=https://www.uantwerpen.be/images/uantwerpen/container2143/files/Publications/DP/2004/01-rafti.pdf|first=Marina|last=Rafti|title=The Rwandan Political Opposition In Exile: A Valid Interlocutor Vis-à-vis Kigali?|work=Institute of Development Policy and Management, [[University of Antwerp]]|pages=26f|date=April 2004}}</ref> He was also unpopular with the old guard of the RDR "because of his leading role in the Rwandan opposition to [[Juvénal Habyarimana]]'s government and his position in the moderate section of the MDR."<ref name=Rafti/> Twagiramungu resigned from the presidency in December 2001 and "essentially detached himself from the opposition movements".<ref name=partywithin/>
On 10 December 2002, Twagiramungu announced that he would be a candidate in the [[Rwandan presidential election, 2003|Rwandan presidential election of 2003]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.irinnews.org/report/43787/rwanda-interview-presidential-hopeful-faustin-twagiramungu|work=[[IRIN]]|title=Interview with presidential hopeful Faustin Twagiramungu|date=16 May 2003|location=Brussels}}</ref> Running on a platform of [[full employment]], regional security, and progressive taxation,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.twagiramungu.net:80/programme.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030903181508/http://www.twagiramungu.net:80/programme.htm|archive-date=3 September 2003|title=Rwanda: berceau de tous les Rwandais|trans-title=Rwanda: Cradle of all Rwandan Peoples|date=February 2003|first=Faustin|last=Twagiramungu|location=Brussels|language=fr}}</ref> he accused the government of attempting to silence his views. He was forced to stand as an independent as his political party, the MDR, was banned.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Guest|first1=Robert|authorlink=Robert Guest|title=[[Borderless Economics|Borderless Economics: Chinese Sea Turtles, Indian Fridges and the New Fruits of Global Capitalism]]|date=2011|publisher=St. Martin's Press|isbn=9780230341234|pages=[https://books.google.no/books?id=8HSp_KW9C-YC&pg=PA138 138f]}}</ref> In the final count, he placed second (out of three) with 3.62 percent of the vote. He did not accept the result, claiming that Paul Kagame was leading the country towards a one-party system.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/a-13-a-2003-08-26-41-faustin/299172.html|work=[[Voice of America]]|title=Faustin Twagiramungu To Challenge Rwandan Election Results|date=26 August 2003}}</ref> The elections were widely condemned as fraudulent by outside observers.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Longman|first1=Timothy|authorlink=Timothy Longman|title=Memory and Justice in Post-Genocide Rwanda|date=2017|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9781107678095|pages=[https://books.google.no/books?id=kLgtDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA164 164]}}</ref> Twagiramungu left Rwanda immediately after the election, fearing arrest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.refworld.org/docid/47d6548ee.html|title=Rwanda: Treatment by government authorities of Faustin Twagiramungu and supporters of his candidacy during the presidential election campaign in August 2003 (August 2003 - April 2006)|id=RWA101284.FE|date=5 May 2006|work=[[Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada]]}}</ref>
In 2010, Twagiramungu founded a "new political trend" called the Rwandan Dream Initiative (RDI).<ref>{{cite web|title=RDI-Rwanda Rwiza Party Manifesto|url=https://medium.com/@rdirwandarwiza/rdi-rwanda-rwiza-party-manifesto-ebc0e5667436|website=RDI-Rwanda Rwiza|accessdate=4 January 2018|date=18 August 2016}}</ref> In early 2014, RDI teamed up with three other parties ([[Social Party Imberakuri|PS-Imberakuri]], {{abbr|UDR|Rwandan Democratic Union}} and [[Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda|FDLR]]) to form the Coalition of Political Parties for Change (CPC). The inclusion of FDLR was a point of controversy.<ref>{{cite news|title=New opposition coalition formed|url=http://country.eiu.com/article.aspx?articleid=1841716968&Country=Rwanda&topic=Politics&subtopic=F_3|work=[[Economist Intelligence Unit]]|date=11 April 2014|language=en}}</ref> The coalition was reportedly falling apart before the end of the year.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rwanda: les FDLR divisent une coalition de l’opposition|url=http://www.rfi.fr/afrique/20141010-rwanda-fdlr-faustin-twagiramungu-opposition-victor-byiringiro|work=[[Radio France Internationale|RFI Afrique]]|language=fr-FR|date=10 October 2014}}</ref>
On 4 April 2014, only two days after Kagame had visited [[Brussels]], Twagiramungu was informed by Belgian police and state security that his life was in danger, and his house was provided with police protection for four days. [[The Globe and Mail]] reported that "there is mounting evidence that Mr. Kagame's agents are involved in organized efforts to kill exiled dissidents".<ref>{{cite news|title=Rwandan dissident in Belgium warned of suspected targeted attack|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/rwandan-dissident-in-belgium-a-suspected-target/article18653424/|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=14 May 2014}}</ref>
