{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Flea | background = solo_singer | image = 2016 RiP Red Hot Chili Peppers - Michael Flea Balzary - by 2eight - DSC0041.jpg | caption = Flea performing with Red Hot Chili Peppers at the 2016 [[Rock am Ring and Rock im Park|Rock im Park]] festival | birth_name = Michael Peter Balzary | alias = Mike B the Flea | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1962|10|16}} | birth_place = [[Melbourne, Victoria]], [[Australia]] | spouse = [[Frankie Rayder (2004-present)]] | genre = {{flatlist| * [[Funk rock]] * [[alternative rock]] * [[funk metal]] * [[jazz]] * [[experimental rock]] * [[punk rock]] * [[jazz-funk]] * [[electronica]] * [[hardcore punk]]}} | occupation = [[Musician]], [[Singing|singer]], [[actor]] | instrument = {{flatlist| * [[Bass guitar]] * [[trumpet]] * [[piano]] * [[keyboards]] * [[Singing|vocals]]}} | years_active = 1979–present | label = {{unbulleted list|[[Warner Bros. Records]]|[[EMI]]}} | associated_acts = {{flatlist| * [[Red Hot Chili Peppers]] * [[Atoms for Peace (band)|Atoms for Peace]] * [[Antemasque (band)|Antemasque]] * [[Rocket Juice & the Moon]] * [[What Is This?]] * [[Fear (band)|Fear]] * [[Jane's Addiction]] * [[The Mars Volta]] * [[Tom Waits]] * [[Alanis Morissette]] * [[Nirvana (band)]] * [[Young MC]]}} | website = }} '''Michael Peter Balzary''' (born October 16, 1962), known professionally as '''Flea''', is an Australian-American musician, singer and actor. He is best known as the bassist and founding member of the rock band [[Red Hot Chili Peppers]].
Flea briefly appeared as the bassist for such bands as [[What Is This?]], [[Fear (band)|Fear]], and [[Jane's Addiction]]. He has performed with rock [[supergroup (music)|supergroup]]s [[Atoms for Peace (band)|Atoms for Peace]], [[Antemasque (band)|Antemasque]], [[Pigface]], and [[Rocket Juice & the Moon]], and collaborated with [[The Mars Volta|Mars Volta]], [[Johnny Cash]], [[Tom Waits]], [[Alanis Morissette]], and [[Young MC]]. Flea also performed live with [[Nirvana (band)|Nirvana]] in 1993 playing the trumpet.
Flea incorporates elements of funk (including [[Slapping (music)|slap bass]]), psychedelic, punk, and hard rock. In 2009, ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' readers ranked Flea the second best bassist of all time, behind only [[John Entwistle]].<ref name="RSTop10">{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/pictures/rolling-stone-readers-pick-the-top-ten-bassists-of-all-time-20110331/2-flea-0428412|title=Rolling Stone Readers Pick the Top Ten Bassists of All Time|publisher=''[[Rolling Stone]]''|accessdate=16 November 2013}}</ref> In 2012, he and the other members of Red Hot Chili Peppers were inducted into the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://rockhall.com/story-of-rock/video-series/video/7638/|title=2012 Hall of Fame Inductee Flea|website=The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum|accessdate=2015-11-30}}</ref>
Since 1984, Flea has acted in over 20 films and television series such as ''[[Suburbia (film)|Suburbia]]'', ''[[Back to the Future Part II]]'' and ''[[Back to the Future Part III|Part III]]'', ''[[My Own Private Idaho]]'', ''[[The Chase (1994 film)|The Chase]]'', ''[[Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas (film)|Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas]]'', ''[[Dudes (film)|Dudes]]'', ''[[Son in Law]]'', ''[[The Big Lebowski]]'', ''[[Low Down]]'', ''[[Baby Driver]]'' and ''[[Boy Erased]]'', in addition to voicing the character [[Donnie Thornberry]] in ''[[The Wild Thornberrys]]'' animated television series and films.
Flea is also the co-founder of [[Silverlake Conservatory of Music]], a non-profit music education organization founded in 2001 for underprivileged children. In 2019 Flea will release his book ''[[Acid for the Children: A Memoir]]'' which will detail his life prior to the formation of Red Hot Chili Peppers.
==Life and career== ===Early life=== Michael Peter Balzary was born on October 16, 1962 in the [[Melbourne]] suburb of [[Burwood], Victoria]]. He is of [[Hungarian people|Hungarian]] and Irish descent. His father, Mick Balzary, an avid fisherman, often took him fishing.<ref name=fcinterview>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DYzpn6vLBgo|title=Red Hot Chili Peppers Fan Club Interview, 1989|publisher=YouTube|accessdate=2007-12-30}}</ref> When Flea was four, his family moved to [[Rye, New York]] for his father's career. In 1971, his parents divorced and his father returned to Australia. Flea and his siblings stayed with their mother Patricia, who soon remarried a [[jazz]] musician.<ref name=apterp19>Apter, 2004. p. 19</ref> Decades later, Flea would receive American citizenship.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/the-red-hot-chili-peppers-rise-again-20000427|title=The Red Hot Chili Peppers Rise Again|work=Rolling Stone|date=April 27, 2000|accessdate=2018-01-26|author=Gavin Edwards}}</ref> He was first called "Flea" as a child for his seeming inability to sit still, and the nickname stuck ever since.<ref>{{cite web|last1=King|first1=Larry|title=Flea on "Larry King Now"|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KiNIWRdm6lE|website=YouTube|accessdate=31 March 2015}}</ref>
Flea's stepfather, Walter Abdul Urban (1941–2011), frequently invited musicians to his house, where [[jam session]]s would often take place. The family moved again to Los Angeles, California, where Flea became fascinated with the trumpet.<ref name=apterpg20>Apter, 2004. p. 20</ref><ref name=AMGbio>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p76467|pure_url=yes}}|title=Biography of Flea|author=Prato, Greg|accessdate=2007-12-15|publisher=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref> He had no interest in rock music at the time; he idolized jazz musicians like [[Miles Davis]], [[Louis Armstrong]] and [[Dizzy Gillespie]].<ref name=apterpg20/> His stepfather was an "aggressive alcoholic", who eventually became involved in shoot-outs with police. "I was raised in a very violent, alcoholic household", Flea later said, "I grew up being terrified of my parents, particularly my father figures. It caused [me] a lot of trouble later in life."<ref name=apterpg21>Apter, 2004. p. 21</ref> To cope, Flea began smoking [[cannabis (drug)|cannabis]] at 13, and became a daily user.<ref name=apterpgs20>Apter, 2004. pp. 22–23</ref>
Flea, who was then nicknamed Mike B. the Flea, attended [[Fairfax High School (Los Angeles)|Fairfax High School]], and was somewhat of an outcast due to his taste in music.<ref name=apterpgs20/> However, he soon met [[Anthony Kiedis]], and after a brief confrontation, the two became best friends.<ref name=apterpg34>Apter, 2004. p. 34</ref> Kiedis recalled: "We were drawn to each other by the forces of mischief and love and we became virtually inseparable. We were both social outcasts. We found each other and it turned out to be the longest-lasting friendship of my life."<ref name=apterpg35>Apter, 2004. p. 35</ref> Flea was turned on to rock music by [[Hillel Slovak]], and particularly [[punk rock]] by Anthony Kiedis. Originally a [[jazz]] trumpet player, Flea learned to play bass from Slovak, who shortly after asked him to be a bassist in his band, [[What Is This?|Anthym]]. Flea soon developed his own style and joined the group, but quit several months later in order to play for the punk rock outfit [[Fear (band)|Fear]]. He then rejoined Slovak to form an intended one-off band: Tony Flow and the Miraculously Majestic Masters of Mayhem along with Kiedis and [[Jack Irons]], all of them at the time inspired by the [[free funk]] band [[Defunkt]] and the [[hip hop]] act [[Grandmaster Flash and The Furious Five]].<ref>Kiedis, Sloman, 2004. pp. 84–85</ref>
===First three Red Hot Chili Peppers albums (1984–1987)=== The band's concert repertoire grew to nine songs as a result of months of playing at local nightclubs and bars.<ref name=apterpg62>Apter, 2004. p. 62</ref> The Red Hot Chili Peppers entered Bijou Studios to record a demo tape produced by the then-drummer of [[Fear (band)|Fear]] and subsequently secured a record deal with [[EMI]].<ref name=VH1behindthemusic>{{cite episode | title = [http://www.vh1.com/shows/dyn/behind_the_music/51363/episode_about.jhtml Red Hot Chili Peppers] | series = [[Behind the Music]] | network = [[VH1]] | airdate = 1999-05-30 | accessdate=2007-08-27}}</ref> Irons and Slovak, however, decided to leave the Red Hot Chili Peppers in order to pursue a "more serious" future with rock band [[What Is This?]]<ref name=apterpgs70>Apter, 2004. pp. 70–74</ref> Flea ultimately respected the decision, but felt the band would be lost without them. He and Kiedis hired drummer [[Cliff Martinez]] and guitarist [[Jack Sherman (guitarist)|Jack Sherman]] to fill Irons's and Slovak's places, respectively.<ref name=apterpgs70/> [[Andy Gill]], formerly of [[Gang of Four (band)|Gang of Four]], agreed to produce their first album. Gill and Sherman clashed with Flea and Kiedis; they continuously argued over music style, sound, and the album's production.<ref name=apterpgs78>Apter, 2004. pp. 78–88</ref> Flea himself felt that the album was stiff and "a big mistake", but also admitted "we [he and Kiedis] were just disrespectful and obnoxious".<ref name=MOJO>Page, Scarlet (July 2004). "Red Hot Chili Peppers: The LA Punks Who Defied Death, Grunge And A Burning Crack Den". ''Mojo''.</ref> The band's eponymous debut album, ''[[The Red Hot Chili Peppers (album)|The Red Hot Chili Peppers]]'', was released on 10 August 1984 to largely poor critical and commercial review.<ref>Kiedis, Sloman, 2004. pp. 234–235</ref> After a relatively unfruitful tour, Sherman was fired in early 1985. Slovak, who had been contemplating a return to the Chili Peppers, rejoined the group after being encouraged by Flea.<ref name=RHCPbio>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p5241|pure_url=yes}}|title=Red Hot Chili Peppers Biography|author=Prato, Greg|accessdate=2007-12-15|publisher=Allmusic}}</ref>
Funk musician [[George Clinton (musician)|George Clinton]] was hired to produce the band's second album, ''[[Freaky Styley]]'' (1985). The strong chemistry between Clinton and the Chili Peppers was felt instantly. Flea later referred to Clinton as "the warmest, kindest man in the world".<ref name=apterpg110>Apter, 2004. p. 110</ref> ''Freaky Styley'' was released in August 1985. It received only a bit more attention than ''The Red Hot Chili Peppers'' with roughly 75,000 copies sold by year's end.<ref name=MOJO/> Flea was somewhat indifferent to the poor album sales as he had recently proposed to girlfriend Loesha Zeviar, who was pregnant with their child.<ref name=apterpg127>Apter, 2004. p. 127</ref> The band hired [[Michael Beinhorn]], their last resort among potential producers, to work on their next album.<ref name=aptr133>Apter, 2004. pp 130–141</ref> What Is This? had finally disbanded, and drummer Irons returned to the Chili Peppers in mid-1986 after Martinez was fired. Flea, Slovak and Kiedis especially were involved in heavy drug use and their relationships became strained. Flea recalled that "it began to seem ugly to me and not fun; our communication was not healthy".<ref name=aptr133/> Kiedis became dependent on heroin, leaving Flea and Slovak to work on much of the album's material by themselves.
Kiedis was briefly kicked out of the band, and given a month to rehabilitate. Kiedis completed the rehab and rejoined the Red Hot Chili Peppers in Los Angeles to record their third album ''[[The Uplift Mofo Party Plan]]'' (1987).<ref name=aptr133/> Flea has referred to the album as "the 'rockingest' record" the band has ever made.<ref name=aptr133/> ''The Uplift Mofo Party Plan'' proved to be far more successful, commercially and critically, than the Chili Peppers' preceding albums, registering at number 148 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]].<ref name=billboardrhcp>{{cite web|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=red hot chili peppers|chart=all}}|title=Red Hot Chili Peppers Chart History|accessdate=2007-09-12|publisher=''Billboard''}}</ref> Following the ''Uplift'' tour, Slovak's drug use dramatically increased. Flea's relationship with Slovak faded, and Slovak became isolated and depressed.<ref name=MOJO/> On 28 June 1988, Slovak was found dead of a heroin overdose. Flea reflected: "I didn't really know how to deal with that sadness, and I don't think [Kiedis] knew how to deal with it either."<ref name=MOJO/> Irons, who was taking Slovak's death particularly hard, left the group.<ref name=VH1behindthemusic/>
Flea and Kiedis took some time to collect themselves, but kept the band together. Guitarist [[DeWayne "Blackbyrd" McKnight]] and drummer [[D.H. Peligro]] were added, and the band entered the studio to record a new album. McKnight soon began to create tension within the group, as his style did not mesh with the rest of the band.<ref name=Kiedis234-239>Kiedis, Sloman, 2004. p. 234</ref> Peligro, the former drummer of the punk rock band [[Dead Kennedys]], was a friend of [[John Frusciante]], an eighteen-year-old guitarist and avid Red Hot Chili Peppers fan.<ref name="rs-fricke">{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/news/coverstory/chilipeppers_tattooed_love_boys/page/1 |author=Fricke, David |date=15 June 2006 |title=Tattooed Love Boys: After twenty-three years, nine albums, death, love, and addiction, the Red Hot Chili Peppers are at Number One for the very first time |accessdate=2007-10-02 |publisher=''Rolling Stone'' |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071001030743/http://www.rollingstone.com/news/coverstory/chilipeppers_tattooed_love_boys/page/1 |archivedate=1 October 2007 }}</ref> Peligro introduced Frusciante to Flea, and the three jammed together on several occasions.<ref name=apterpg178>Apter, 2004. pp. 178–190</ref> Flea was impressed with Frusciante's skill, and astonished by his knowledge of the Chili Peppers' repertoire. Flea realized that Frusciante could provide the spark McKnight was lacking.<ref name=MMliner>''Mother's Milk'' 2003 reissue liner notes</ref> McKnight was fired, and Frusciante accepted an invitation to join the band.<ref name=Kiedis234-239/> Peligro was fired shortly thereafter; the Chili Peppers brought in drummer [[Chad Smith]] as his replacement.<ref>Kiedis, Sloman, 2004. p. 242</ref>
===Mainstream success and side projects (1989–1998)===
Flea and his wife Loesha started to grow apart, and he began trying to recreate the memories of his adolescence by smoking marijuana on a daily basis.<ref name="apterpg178" /> The Chili Peppers entered the studio, and completed recording of their fourth album, ''[[Mother's Milk]]'', in early 1989. Upon release, the album was met with mixed reactions from critics, but received far more commercial attention, peaking at number fifty-two on the ''Billboard'' 200.<ref name="billboardrhcp" /> After this, Flea made appearances playing the trumpet on Jane's Addiction's 1988 album ''[[Nothing's Shocking]]'',<ref name="jans">''Nothing's Shocking'' liner notes</ref> and bass on the critically acclaimed 1989 [[Young MC]] album ''[[Stone Cold Rhymin']]''. He would also appear in the video for "[[Bust a Move (song)|Bust a Move]]", the hit single from the same album.<ref>{{cite web| title = Stone Cold Rhymin' credits | publisher = Allmusic | url = {{Allmusic|class=album|id=r28418|pure_url=yes}} | accessdate = 2008-05-29}}</ref> [[File:RedHotChiliPeppersAdam1989.jpg|thumb|left|Flea (right) and Anthony Kiedis in Amsterdam, 1989]]
The ensuing ''[[Mother's Milk Tour]]'' put even further strain on Flea's marriage. In order to make money, he needed to tour, and therefore spent time away from his family.<ref name="apterpg205">Apter, 2004. pp. 205–212</ref> Furthermore, he and Smith were arrested on charges of battery and sexual harassment after a performance on [[MTV]]'s coverage of spring break;<ref name="MOJO" /> charges were eventually dropped.<ref name="apterpg205" /> The band was, however, attracting over three thousand people per show; ''Mother's Milk'' had been [[RIAA certification|certified]] as a [[Music recording sales certification|gold]] record in early 1990.<ref name="RIAA">{{cite web|url=http://riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH|title=RIAA Searchable Database|publisher=[[RIAA]]|accessdate=2007-12-15}}</ref><ref name="Billboard singles">{{cite web| url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=red hot chili peppers|chart=all}}|title=Red Hot Chili Peppers Artist Chart History: Singles| publisher=''[[Billboard magazine|Billboard]]''| accessdate=2011-06-18}}</ref> By the time Red Hot Chili Peppers returned to Los Angeles, Flea and Loesha agreed to a separation.<ref name="apterpg205" /> He tried to put the separation out of his mind by smoking marijuana and having sex with random [[groupie]]s, when the band was on tour for ''Mother's Milk''.<ref name="apterpg205" />
When the successful Mother's Milk tour was over, the Red Hot Chili Peppers severed ties with EMI and signed with [[Warner Bros. Records]].<ref name="sctisswarner">Kiedis, Sloman, 2004. pp. 261–262</ref> [[Rick Rubin]], who had rejected an opportunity to produce ''The Uplift Mofo Party Plan'', agreed to produce their next album.<ref name="apterpg220">Apter, 2004. pp. 220–236</ref> Flea had largely used the principal [[Slapping (music)|slap bass]] technique on the band's preceding four albums, and decided to downplay this style in favor of more conventional, melodic bass lines.<ref name="Funkymonks">''Funky Monks'', 1991. Warner Bros. Entertainment, Inc.</ref> To record the album, Rubin suggested they use a mansion that once belonged to magician [[Harry Houdini]]. Flea felt it was "a creatively fertile situation", and decided to bring his daughter Clara with him.<ref name="apterpg220" /> He and the rest of the band, excluding Smith, remained inside the house for the entire recording process. When not writing or recording the album, Flea spent a large portion of his time with Frusciante smoking large quantities of marijuana.<ref name="apterpg220" /> The emotions Flea felt during the album's recording were like nothing he had ever experienced:<ref name="MOJO" /> {{cquote|When we [the band] made ''Blood Sugar Sex Magik'' we spent a lot of time jamming—every day, for hours and hours. I remember during that time Anthony went off and made a movie, and for a long time it was just me, John and Chad, and we'd just go in there and play. Me and John were hitting the bong and we just rocked and grooved forever. It was the first time we went in to make a record where there wasn't this feeling of being sort of intimidated by what was going to happen.}}
When ''[[Blood Sugar Sex Magik]]'' was released on 24 September 1991, it received an overwhelmingly positive critical response. The album peaked at number three on the ''Billboard'' Hot 200, and went on to sell over seven million copies in the U.S. alone.<ref name=RHCPbio/><ref name=billboardrhcp/> The album's ensuing tour was critically acclaimed – the Chili Peppers commonly performed shows with over twenty thousand in attendance.<ref name=p282>Kiedis, Sloman, 2004. p. 282</ref> [[Seattle]]-based [[grunge]] band [[Nirvana (band)|Nirvana]] also toured with them during the West Coast leg of their United States tour.<ref name=p282/> The massive attention the Chili Peppers started receiving, however, caused Frusciante to feel extremely uncomfortable, and he abruptly quit the band during the Japanese leg of the album's tour.<ref name=rollingstonearticle>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/artists/redhotchilipeppers/articles/story/5938432/the_naked_truth |title=The Naked Truth |first=David |last=Fricke |accessdate=2007-08-10 |publisher=''Rolling Stone'' |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071002105938/http://www.rollingstone.com/artists/redhotchilipeppers/articles/story/5938432/the_naked_truth |archivedate=2 October 2007 }}</ref>
Following the tour in 1993, Flea was diagnosed with [[chronic fatigue syndrome]] and was ordered to rest for a year.<ref>{{cite book | last = Fitzpatrick | first = R | year = 2004 | publisher = [[Da Capo Press]] | title = Red Hot Chili Peppers: Give It Away: The Stories Behind Every Song | isbn = 1-56025-579-X | pages = [https://books.google.com/books?id=pOnaN4uPapMC&pg=PA140#v=onepage&q&f=false 140] }}</ref> Flea and Kiedis felt it best to fire Marshall due to lack of chemistry and briefly replaced him with [[Jesse Tobias]] although his tenure was very short and he was quickly replaced by [[Jane's Addiction]] guitarist [[Dave Navarro]], who was once recruited in 1992 to replace Frusciante. The band was ready now to record their next album although Kiedis was in the middle of a heroin relapse, which forced Flea to assume the role of lyricist, something he had not yet done. He wrote most of the song "Transcending", and the intro to "Deep Kick". Flea also wrote the lyrics to an entire song; "Pea", in which he both played bass and sang.<ref name=p341>Kiedis, Sloman, 2004. pp. 341–344</ref> These three songs appeared on the Chili Peppers' sixth record ''[[One Hot Minute]]'', which was released on 12 September 1995. The album received mixed reviews and was significantly less commercially successful than ''Blood Sugar Sex Magik''.<ref name=RHCPbio/> The ''[[One Hot Minute Tour]]'' was ultimately cut short due to various injuries Kiedis and Smith received, and the Red Hot Chili Peppers decided to go on hiatus. Flea was so miserable that at one point during the tour he discussed quitting the band.<ref name=apterpg290>Apter, 2004. pp. 290–302</ref> Flea began to practice [[Transcendental Meditation]]<ref>SONS OF THE CITY, by John Albert, 6 December 2002, LA Weekly (California)</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=JheoECFjDqMC&pg=PA46&lpg=PA46&dq=michael+balzary+flea+meditation&source=bl&ots=ykVGk2FSYI&sig=atzJmJml1kYB7frkDJL7POifY1k&hl=en&sa=X&ei=JoshT4jME-HW2AWFnKnfDw&ved=0CCIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=michael%20balzary%20flea%20meditation&f=false "To Live and Die in LA"] April 1996, Spin Magazine</ref> and [[yoga]], and slowly decreased his marijuana consumption.<ref name=apterpg290/> Due to the Chili Peppers' inactivity, Flea joined Navarro in a Jane's Addiction reunion tour in 1997, filling in for ex-Jane's Addiction bassist [[Eric Avery]]. Rumors spread, that the band was breaking up until Navarro stated otherwise: "I want to clarify that the Chili Peppers are not breaking up ... Flea and I are more than happy to do both projects, time permitting."<ref name=apterpg290/>
Flea also had plans to record a solo album. He asked Chili Peppers manager [[Lindy Goetz]] to help him promote the record and his future solo career.<ref name=apterpg290/> Flea eventually abandoned the idea in favor of offering his bass services to other artists. He performed on over forty records from 1995 to 1998, ranging from [[Alanis Morissette]]'s ''[[Jagged Little Pill]]'' to former [[Minutemen (band)|Minutemen]] bassist [[Mike Watt]]'s debut solo album ''[[Ball-Hog or Tugboat?]]''. He also worked with [[Tori Amos]] and [[Michael Stipe]] on a track for the soundtrack to the 1995 [[Johnny Depp]] film ''[[Don Juan DeMarco]]''.<ref>Apter, 2004. p. 281</ref> Navarro was fired from the Chili Peppers in 1998, and Flea questioned whether or not the Red Hot Chili Peppers would stay together: "... the only way I could imagine carrying on is if we got John [Frusciante] back in the band."<ref name=pp2>Kiedis, Sloman, 2004. pp. 390–395</ref> Frusciante had completed drug rehabilitation in 1997 after a severe addiction to heroin and [[crack cocaine]] left him on the brink of death.<ref name="pnt">{{cite web | last = Wilonsky | first = Robert | url = http://www.phoenixnewtimes.com/1996-12-12/music/blood-on-the-tracks/| title = Blood on the Tracks | publisher = ''Phoenix New Times Music'' | date = 12 December 1996 | accessdate = 2007-06-22 }}</ref> Flea visited Frusciante in early 1998, inviting him back to the Chili Peppers; an emotional Frusciante readily accepted.<ref>Kiedis, Sloman, 2004. p. 408</ref>
===''Californication'', ''By the Way'' and ''Stadium Arcadium'' (1998–2007)===
The band, with Frusciante back on guitar, began writing new songs during the summer of 1998 in Flea's garage.<ref name=MOJO/> He and Kiedis were less confident in writing the album after the disappointing results of ''One Hot Minute''.<ref name=MOJO/> Flea had also recently broken up with his girlfriend of two years, Marissa Pouw, causing him to enter a state of depression<ref name=apterpg300>Apter, 2004. pp. 304–311</ref> which was only lifted when his daughter, Clara, comforted him after several weeks of crying.<ref name=MOJO/>
Flea was heavily influenced by [[electronica]] during the writing and recording of ''[[Californication (album)|Californication]]'' (1999) and he attempted to emulate this when writing bass lines for the album.<ref name=apterpg300/> ''Californication'' took less than two weeks to record; by contrast, ''One Hot Minute'' took over a year. When ''Californication'' was released on 8 June 1999 it received overwhelmingly positive critical reviews and sold fifteen million copies worldwide – more than ''Blood Sugar Sex Magik''.<ref name=MOJO/> The Chili Peppers played [[Woodstock 1999]], with Flea playing completely naked – something he would do again at the [[Reading and Leeds Festivals]] the same year as well as several other ''Californication'' tour concerts.<ref name=apterpg300/>
Red Hot Chili Peppers spent most of 2001 writing their eighth studio album, ''[[By the Way]]'' (2002). The entire band began listening to more melodic, textured music, that would reflect heavily on the album.<ref name=MOJO/> Frusciante became the driving force behind ''By the Way'', causing initial strife between him and Flea.<ref name=apterpg300/> If he introduced a funk rhythm into his bass lines Frusciante would consequently disapprove to the point where Flea almost quit the band because he felt his role was no longer important.<ref name=apterpg300/> ''By the Way'' was released on 9 July 2002 to positive critical reviews. ''By the Way'' would go on to sell over nine million copies worldwide.<ref name=btwsales>{{cite web|url=http://www.ultimate-guitar.com/news/online_downloads/red_hot_chili_peppers_first_single_preview_posted_online.html|title=Red Hot Chili Peppers: First Single Preview|publisher=Total Guitar|accessdate=2007-10-09}}</ref> The ensuing tour was extremely profitable; the Chili Peppers performed three concerts in London's [[Hyde Park, London|Hyde Park]] to over 250,000 attendees and a total gross accumulation of US$17.1 million.<ref name=yahoonews>{{cite web|url=http://new.music.yahoo.com/john-frusciante/news/chili-peppers-hot-in-londons-hyde-park--12178349|title=Chili Peppers Hot in London's Hyde Park|author=Waddell, Ray|date=June 2007|publisher=Yahoo! Music|accessdate=2008-01-20|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110812221031/http://new.music.yahoo.com/john-frusciante/news/chili-peppers-hot-in-londons-hyde-park--12178349|archivedate=12 August 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> It became the highest-grossing concert at a single venue in history.<ref name=yahoonews/>
After another two-year world tour, the Chili Peppers wrote their ninth studio album ''[[Stadium Arcadium]]'' (2006).<ref name=itunesinterview>Red Hot Chili Peppers. [[iTunes Originals]]. iTunes. 8 September 2006</ref> Unlike ''By the Way'', both Flea and Frusciante were more musically conjoined, when writing the record. They found inspiration in [[Jimi Hendrix]], [[Jimmy Page]], and [[Eddie Van Halen]] among others.<ref name=interview2006>{{cite video|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g9E8livzmRM|date=2006|people = Gallori, Paolo|title=Intervista a John Frusciante|publisher=YouTube|medium=TV interview|accessdate=2007-12-16}}</ref> The double album was ultimately released on 9 May 2006, to generally positive reviews, selling over seven million copies in less than two years.<ref name=stadiumsales>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/liveearth/artists/redhotchilipeppers/|title=Red Hot Chili Peppers – Live Earth |date=June 2007|publisher=BBC|accessdate=2007-10-11}}</ref> In November 2007, Flea's $4.8 million Corral Canyon home in [[Malibu, California|Malibu]] was burnt down by a wildfire.<ref name=BBCfire>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/7113043.stm|title=Fire wrecks Chili Pepper's home|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=2008-01-27 | date=26 November 2007}}</ref> The location was not, however, his primary residence<ref name=BBCfire/> and at the time of its destruction was being rented to musician and producer [[Butch Walker]].<ref>{{Cite news| last =Orzeck| first =Kurt| title =Avril Lavigne producer Butch Walker was renting Flea's Malibu house; he 'lost everything'| publisher =[[MTV (Canada)|MTV.ca]] news| date =27 November 2007| url =http://www.mtv.ca/news/article.jhtml?id=5523| accessdate =2007-11-27| archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20110721225424/http://www.mtv.ca/news/article.jhtml?id=5523| archive-date =21 July 2011| dead-url =yes| df =dmy-all}}</ref>
===Chili Peppers hiatus, return to school, Atoms for Peace, and ''Helen Burns'' (2008–2012)===
After the Chili Peppers announced a long hiatus due to exhaustion, Flea enrolled in music classes at the [[University of Southern California]]. Beginning in the fall of 2008, he studied [[music theory]], composition and jazz trumpet. Flea attributed his interest in attending such courses to a newfound desire to widen his appreciation and understanding of music: "it's so much fun to learn this stuff because I never knew anything. I played trumpet in the school bands. I learned things I liked to play on my trumpet but I didn't learn why this note goes with this note and why it produces that sound. Or how to create tension in the composition [...] Knowing the structure is really fun."<ref name=latimes08>{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/soundboard/2008/09/flea-usc-freshm.html|title=Flea, USC freshman, talks about his upcoming solo record|author=Wells, Annie|date=23 September 2008|publisher=''Los Angeles Times''|accessdate=2008-09-29|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080927043430/http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/soundboard/2008/09/flea-usc-freshm.html <!--Added by H3llBot-->|archivedate=27 September 2008}}</ref> Flea also revealed plans to release a mainly instrumental solo record, recorded in his home; guest musicians include [[Patti Smith]] and a choir from the Silverlake Conservatory.<ref name=latimes08/>
In 2009, Flea joined [[Atoms for Peace (band)|Atoms for Peace]], a supergroup formed by Radiohead singer [[Thom Yorke]] to perform songs from his debut solo album, ''[[The Eraser]]'' (2006).<ref name=":02">{{cite web|url=http://www.factmag.com/2013/01/28/atoms-for-peace-thom-yorke-interview/|title=A New Career in a New Town: Radiohead’s Thom Yorke and Nigel Godrich open Pandora’s Box and run AMOK as Atoms for Peace|accessdate=2015-05-02}}</ref> The band toured the United States in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stereogum.com/278731/thom-yorke-names-his-band-announces-tour-dates/news/|title=Thom Yorke Names His ???? Band Atoms For Peace, Announces Tour Dates|website=Stereogum|access-date=2016-04-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/38018-thom-yorke-names-solo-band-lines-up-american-spring-tour/|title=Thom Yorke Names Solo Band, Lines Up American Spring Tour|last=Dombal|first=Ryan|date=25 February 2010|publisher=[[Pitchfork Media]]|accessdate=2010-03-02|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100227180356/http://pitchfork.com/news/38018-thom-yorke-names-solo-band-lines-up-american-spring-tour/|archivedate=2010-02-27 <!--DASHBot-->|deadurl=no}}</ref> After the tour, Atoms for Peace spent three days [[Jam session|jamming]] and recording original material in Los Angeles. This became the band's debut album, [[Amok (Atoms for Peace album)|''Amok'']]'',''<ref name="roll2">{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/blogs/alternate-take/q-a-thom-yorke-on-atoms-for-peaces-mechanistic-new-album-20121105|title=Q&A: Thom Yorke on Atoms for Peace's 'Mechanistic' New Album|date=5 November 2012|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|accessdate=18 Feb 2013}}</ref> released on 25 February 2013, through [[XL Recordings]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://xlrecordings.com/calendar|title=Calendar|date=|publisher=Xlrecordings.com|accessdate=2013-02-24|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130403135345/http://xlrecordings.com/calendar|archivedate=2013-04-03|df=}}</ref> The album was followed that year by a tour of Europe, the US, and Japan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/49991-atoms-for-peace-announce-us-and-japanese-dates/|title=Atoms for Peace Announce U.S. and Japanese Dates|website=Pitchfork|language=en-US|accessdate=2015-11-13}}</ref>
The Chili Peppers ended their hiatus in October 2009 without Frusciante, who quit the band in order to pursue other musical interests. He was replaced by [[Josh Klinghoffer]]. The band began rehearsing and writing for their tenth studio album.<ref>{{cite web|last=Montgomery|first=James|title=Red Hot Chili Peppers Say Josh Klinghoffer Was 'The Only Choice'|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1670041/red-hot-chili-peppers-josh-klinghoffer.jhtml|work=[[MTV.com]]|accessdate=20 November 2011|date=31 August 2011}}</ref><ref name="allmusic I'm with You review">{{cite web|last=Erlewine|first=Stephen Thomas|title=I'm with You – Red Hot Chili Peppers|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/im-with-you-r2254734/review|work=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=20 November 2011}}</ref>
In April 2011, Flea finished second in an online poll conducted by Contact Music to name the best bass guitarist in rock music. Flea lost to the late [[John Entwistle]] of [[the Who]]. Rounding out the top five were [[Paul McCartney]] ([[the Beatles]]), [[Geddy Lee]] ([[Rush (band)|Rush]]) and [[Les Claypool]] ([[Primus (band)|Primus]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/news.nsf/story/john-entwistle-named-best-bassist_1210683 |title=The Who | John Entwistle Named Best Bassist |publisher=Contactmusic |date=1 April 2011 |accessdate=2011-05-28}}</ref>
In June 2011, Flea announced that he was giving away a personally customized bass guitar covered with graffiti and a one-on-one bass lesson as a prize in an [[eBay]] auction. The auction will benefit ''[[Style Wars]]'', a 1983 documentary on early [[hip hop]]. The auction will raise money for restoring the film's negatives. [[Brad Pitt]], [[James Franco]], and [[Spike Jonze]] also took part in the auction, which ended on 11 June 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.express.co.uk/posts/view/251365/Flea-donates-bass-guitar-to-charity-auctionFlea-donates-bass-guitar-to-charity-auction#ixzz1Oi6gtFKU|title=Flea donates bass guitar to charity auction|publisher=Express.co.uk|date=9 June 2011 |accessdate=2011-06-09}}</ref>
In a 23 June 2011 interview, Flea discussed the band's return and how he almost quit the Chili Peppers during their hiatus. Flea said, that he just felt like he wanted to take two years away just to really look and see if the band was "something we should still be doing". "Things had gotten dysfunctional and not fun, even though I thought we were making great records, doing great shows and were a really powerful, mighty thing as a band. I was proud of what we did." "For me, the biggest thing during the time off, and what really made me want to continue doing the band, specifically after decided he didn't want to continue in the band anymore, [was] I just realized, Anthony, man, he's my brother, I love him so much, and we started this band when we were kids. I wanted to keep that going, I never want to let that go. Playing with him is something, even though I can do other things that are exciting and beautiful and I always will do those things and I'll always want to grow and do music outside of the band, the thing that we have is special to us and something that is blood."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spinner.com/2011/06/23/red-hot-chili-peppers-im-with-you/|title=Red Hot Chili Peppers' Flea Admits Band Nearly Split During 'Dysfunctional' Period|work=Spinner}}</ref>
The Red Hot Chili Peppers released their tenth studio album, ''[[I'm with You (album)|I'm with You]]'' on 29 August 2011.
Flea played bass on 2 songs on [[Tom Waits]]'s 2011 album ''[[Bad as Me]]'', released on 21 October.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://popblerd.com/2011/10/26/spin-cycle-tom-waits-bad-as-me/ |title=Spin Cycle: Tom Waits' "Bad As Me" |publisher=: |date=26 October 2011 |accessdate=2012-12-19}}</ref>
On 27 October 2011, it was announced that Flea's side-project with [[Damon Albarn]] and afrobeat legend, [[Tony Allen (musician)|Tony Allen]] would be called [[Rocket Juice & the Moon]]. According to Albarn, on where the band's name came from, someone in [[Lagos]] did the sleeve design and that's the name he gave it, which he said he is fine with, because trying to find a name for another band is always tricky. The band made their live debut on 29 October 2011, in London and their debut album was released in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/music/news/a347880/damon-albarn-flea-to-release-album-as-rocketjuice-and-the-moon.html |title=Damon Albarn, Flea to release album as Rocketjuice and the Moon – Music News – Digital Spy |publisher=Digitalspy.com |date=27 October 2011 |accessdate=2012-12-19}}</ref>
On 7 December 2011, the Red Hot Chili Peppers were announced as 2012 inductees into the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]]. Flea commented on the induction by saying, "It's always been easy for me to pooh-pooh these awards – the [Rock] Hall of Fame too. But I inducted [[Metallica]] a couple of years ago, and it was really a beautiful thing to see as all these people were being inducted. It made me love it. I love halls of fame anyway – the [[Basketball Hall of Fame]], the [[Baseball Hall of Fame]]. So I feel grateful for the recognition of what we have done and for the hope and potential of what we'll continue to do."<ref> {{cite news| url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/music_blog/2011/12/red-hot-chili-peppers-rock-hall-fame-flea.html | work=Los Angeles Times | title=Pop & Hiss | date=7 December 2011}}</ref>
The debut album by Rocketjuice and the Moon was released on 12 March 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gibson.com/en-us/Lifestyle/News/albarn-allen-flea-0104-2012/ |title=Chili Peppers' Flea and Blur's Damon Albarn Talk New Group: Rocketjuice and the Moon |publisher=Gibson.com |accessdate=2012-12-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120311024733/http://www.gibson.com/en%2Dus/Lifestyle/News/albarn%2Dallen%2Dflea%2D0104%2D2012/ |archive-date=11 March 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
[[File:Flea 1012 (2).jpg|thumb|upright|Flea performing with the Red Hot Chili Peppers in 2012]] On 19 July 2012, Flea released a solo EP, ''[[Helen Burns (EP)|Helen Burns]]'', composed mainly of instrumental tracks, except the title track (which [[Patti Smith]] sang on) and "Lovelovelove", which features the [[Silverlake Conservatory of Music]]'s kids and adults choir. It is Flea's first solo release, who has only released solo songs previously on soundtracks and other projects. Flea said of the EP "I am putting it out to raise money for the Silverlake Conservatory of Music, a community based non-profit music school that I am an integral part of." The download of the EP is available at "[[Pay what you want|a name your own price]]" on the Silverlake Conservatory website and will be made available through all major digital outlets 9 August 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://redhotchilipeppers.com/news/367-helen-burns-flea |title=Helen Burns – Flea – RHCP News |publisher=Redhotchilipeppers.com |accessdate=2012-12-19}}</ref>
On 16 October 2012, his 50th birthday, Flea gave an interview with [[CNN]] discussing the Chili Peppers and was asked if he plans to continue with them. Flea responded by saying "I love the Chili Peppers, and I would love to. If there's anything I know, it's every time you start making plans, you don't know what's going to come up next. Anything can happen. So I love being in the Chili Peppers and it's my home, and I've been doing it for more than half my life. Of course, during the course of doing it, there's been all kinds of ups and downs, and moments of extreme (positivity), floating on clouds of greatness, and times of just groveling, and misery, and uncertainty, and anger, and love and all those things. Like being in a family. I really can't predict. But I love being in it for now, and right now, about as far as I'm thinking is getting through this tour that we're doing, performing at the highest level possible, then hunkering down and writing another record."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/10/17/showbiz/music/flea-red-hot-chili-peppers-50th-birthday/index.html |title=A Chili Pepper turns 50 |publisher=CNN.com |accessdate=2012-12-19 |date=17 October 2012}}</ref>
===Return to acting, ''The Getaway'' (2014–present)=== It was announced on 1 April 2014 that Flea was in the process of writing his own personal memoir which will be released through Grand Central Publishing. No release date has been set or a title for the book which according to the press release will detail Flea's younger years as a rebellious teenager on the streets of L.A. where he befriends fellow high school classmate, Anthony Kiedis, Hillel Slovak and Jack Irons and forms the Red Hot Chili Peppers. The book will detail his long and sometimes complex friendship and collaboration with Kiedis, his drug usage and the tumultuous creative journey of the band.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/books/2014/04/01/book-buzz-flea-memoir-red-hot-chili-peppers/7158549/ | work=USA Today | title=Flea of Red Hot Chili Peppers is writing memoir | date=1 April 2014}}</ref>
On 9 April 2014, it was revealed that Flea was working on a new musical project titled [[Antemasque (band)|Antemasque]], with former Mars Volta members [[Cedric Bixler-Zavala]], [[Omar Rodríguez-López]], and [[Dave Elitch]]. Two songs were released in early April though Flea has confirmed that he is not a member of the band and just recorded a few songs with them.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nme.com/news/the-mars-volta/76609 | title=Former Mars Volta members form new group with Red Hot Chili Peppers' Flea | publisher=[[NME]] | date=9 April 2014 | accessdate=9 April 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Grow |first=Kory |url=http://m.rollingstone.com/music/news/fleas-new-supergroup-antemasque-share-another-prog-punk-rager-20140410 |title=Flea's New Supergroup With Mars Volta Members Antemasque Share Another Prog-Punk Rager | Music News | Rolling Stone |publisher=M.rollingstone.com |date=2014-04-10 |accessdate=2014-07-15}}</ref> Antemasque released their self-titled debut album on 15 July 2014.
Flea made his return to acting and co-starred in the 2014 film, ''[[Low Down]]'', which is based on the life of jazz pianist, [[Joe Albany]]. Flea along with Anthony Kiedis executive produced the film which stars [[John Hawkes (actor)|John Hawkes]], [[Elle Fanning]], [[Glenn Close]], and [[Peter Dinklage]]. The film had a successful debut at the [[Sundance Film Festival]] in January 2014 and opened in limited release in October 2014. It was released in March 2015 on DVD.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.indiewire.com/2014/09/watch-john-hawkes-is-elle-fannings-heroin-addicted-father-in-low-down-69893/ | title=Watch: John Hawkes is Elle Fanning’s Heroin-Addicted Father In ‘Low Down’ | publisher=IndieWire | date=18 September 2014 | first=Zainab | last=Akande | accessdate=8 April 2017 }}</ref>
In February 2015, Flea posted photos to his [[Instagram]] page showing that he had broken his arm during a skiing trip. His injury delayed the recording of the Chili Peppers eleventh studio album for six months with production expected to resume in mid-August according to Flea, who said on 3 August, he was now healed enough to play bass again and continue recording.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://exclaim.ca/Music/article/flea_breaks_arm_in_apparent_skiing_accident| work=Exclaim| title=Flea Breaks Arm in Apparent Skiing Accident| date=17 February 2015}}</ref>
On 13 April 2016, Flea performed a bass rendition of ''[[The Star-Spangled Banner]]'' before a game at the [[Staples Center]] in Los Angeles between the [[Los Angeles Lakers]] and [[Utah Jazz]]; this was NBA superstar [[Kobe Bryant]]'s final game.
The Chili Peppers released their eleventh studio album, ''[[The Getaway (Red Hot Chili Peppers album)|The Getaway]],'' on June 17, 2016. The band embarked on a 151 date world-tour which concluded in October 2017.
In 2017 Flea appeared in the critically acclaimed movie ''[[Baby Driver]]'' which was named one of the top 10 films of the year by the [[National Board of Review]]
On February 16, 2018, Flea took part in the 2018 NBA All-Star Celebrity Game on a team led by [[Justin Bieber]].<ref>{{cite web|author=February 17, 2018 |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/watch-win-butler-justin-bieber-120215375.html |title=Watch Win Butler, Justin Bieber, & Quavo Play In The NBA All-Star Celebrity Game |publisher=Sports.yahoo.com |date=2018-02-17 |accessdate=2018-06-19}}</ref>
==Personal life== From 1988 to 1990, Flea was married to Loesha Zeviar (Loesha's name still remains tattooed on Flea's chest). Together they had one daughter, Clara Balzary, who was born in 1988. Clara has been featured in many Chili Peppers books and documentaries including the band's ''[[Funky Monks]]'' documentary. She also has appeared at many shows and as a child even provided artwork for the band's T-shirts and promotional material.<ref>{{IMDb name|id=2497806|name=Clara Balzary|section=bio}}</ref> She has also documented the band's ''I'm With You'' tour through photographs and videos. As an adult, Clara was most recently in the short-lived band the Tints<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.purevolume.com/thetintsca |title=The Tints (Ca) on |publisher=Purevolume.com |accessdate=2011-05-28}}</ref> and is also an aspiring artist and photographer, taking the promotional photographs for the new Red Hot Chili Peppers record.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clara-balzary.com/ |title=Clara Balzary |publisher=Clara Balzary |accessdate=2011-05-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://blog.urbanoutfitters.com/features/about_a_girl_clara_balzary |title=Urban Outfitters – Features – Clara Balzary |publisher=Blog.urbanoutfitters.com |accessdate=2011-05-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005051802/http://blog.urbanoutfitters.com/features/about_a_girl_clara_balzary |archivedate=5 October 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Flea married for the second time in 2005 to model [[Frankie Rayder]] who was once named [[GQ Magazine]]'s sexiest woman in the world. They had their first child together, Sunny Bebop Balzary, who was born on October 26, 2005.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.starglimpse.com/celebs/pages/frankie_rayder/frankie_rayder.shtml |title=Frankie Rayder – Biography, Movies, Photos, Videos, News |publisher=Starglimpse.com |accessdate=2011-05-28}}</ref><ref>{{IMDb name|id=0281359|section=bio|name=Flea|accessdate=2014-07-15}}</ref> The song "Hard to Concentrate" on the Chili Peppers' 2006 album, ''[[Stadium Arcadium]]'' was written by Kiedis as a wedding proposal to Flea and Rayder.
Flea was close friends with actor [[River Phoenix]] and was with him on 31 October 1993, the night he died of a drug overdose, even riding in the ambulance to the hospital with him. The song "Transcending" on ''One Hot Minute'' was a tribute to Phoenix written by Flea.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2429749/River-Phoenix-knew-suffering-overdose-night-died-says-friend.html| title = How River Phoenix KNEW he was suffering an overdose the night he died: Friend reveals the actor's harrowing last few minutes before he collapsed at Johnny Depp's LA nightclub almost 20 years ago| first= James| last= Nye | work =The Daily Mail| date= 22 September 2013 | accessdate= 31 October 2015}}</ref>
In the 2011 documentary ''The Other F Word'', Flea discussed the joys of being a father by saying "It's funny how you always hear people saying that classic parent attitude of, 'I brought you into this world, I gave you life!' You know, it's just, I think, completely the opposite. My kids gave me life. They gave me a reason."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.celebritybabyscoop.com/2011/05/10/flea |title=Flea & His Girls: Strollin’ In NYC |publisher=Celebrity Baby Scoop |date=2011-05-10 |accessdate=2014-07-15}}</ref>
Flea is a fan of the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] and [[Los Angeles Lakers]]. He can often be spotted sitting courtside at Lakers games with some of his bandmates and has even performed the [[National Anthem]] prior to Lakers games.<ref name=nba>{{cite web|title=Top 10 Celebrity Lakers Fans|url=http://www.nba.com/features/lakers_celebs_070309.html|publisher=NBA|accessdate=7 February 2013}}</ref> He is also known to be a fan of English football team [[Sheffield United]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/nov/23/bands-versions-football-club-songs | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=John | last=Ashdown | title=Which bands have performed versions of football club songs? | date=23 November 2011}}</ref>
In February 2018, Flea released a passionate and revealing [[op-ed]] through [[Time magazine]] about the current [[Opioid crisis]] as well as his own personal history of drug addiction which for most of his career he had been very private about. Flea hoped that by exposing his past issues with substance abuse that his stories could possibly help others battling their own addictions and raise more awareness on the need for those in the medical community and the government to help those in need. "I’ve been around substance abuse since the day I was born. All the adults in my life regularly numbed themselves to ease their troubles, and alcohol or drugs were everywhere, always. I started smoking weed when I was eleven, and then proceeded to snort, shoot, pop, smoke, drop and dragon chase my way through my teens and twenties," Flea said. Flea finally kicked his addictions in 1993; however, he revealed that in 2014 when he broke his arm in a snowboard accident he nearly had setbacks due to [[Oxycontin]] that his doctor prescribed for him "My doctor put me back together perfectly, and thanks to him I can still play bass with all my heart. But he also gave me two-month supply of Oxycontin. The bottle said to take four each day. I was high as hell when I took those things. It not only quelled my physical pain, but all my emotions as well. I only took one a day, but I was not present for my kids, my creative spirit went into decline and I became depressed. I stopped taking them after a month, but I could have easily gotten another refill. Addiction is a cruel disease, and the medical community, together with the government, should offer help to all of those who need it."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://time.com/5168435/flea-temptation-drug-addiction-opioid-crisis/| work=Time| title=Flea: The Temptation of Drugs Is a Bitch| date=February 28, 2018}}</ref>
===Activism and philanthropy=== Flea and the Chili Peppers appeared in 1990 [[Public service announcement|PSA]] ads for [[Rock the Vote]], a [[non-profit]] organization created to encourage 18- to 24-year-olds in the United States to vote in the upcoming presidential election.
The Chili Peppers were invited by the [[Beastie Boys]] and the [[Milarepa Fund]] to perform at the [[Tibetan Freedom Concert]] in June 1996 in [[San Francisco]]. They also performed at the June 1998 [[Washington DC]] concert as well. The concerts, which were held worldwide, were to support the cause of [[Tibetan independence]].
In 2001, he founded the [[Silverlake Conservatory of Music]], a school dedicated to help youth progress in music, because of this.<ref name=laist/><ref name=apterpg320>Apter, 2004. pp. 327–338</ref> "I just wanted to fill the void that public education has cut from their curriculum. They've dropped the ball by cutting out music programs", Flea laments, "I grew up in LA public schools and was in the music department. It was really an important thing for my life, it gave me something to hold onto, and it was an important access for me. Without music I would've gotten into a lot of trouble and there are a lot of kids like me out there. I just wanted to try to provide something like what I got."<ref name=laist/> Flea felt the public school system was seriously lacking in exposing children to music by drastically reducing, and sometimes eliminating, art-related programs.<ref name=laist>{{cite web|url=http://www.laist.com/2007/05/02/fleas_circus_silverlake_music_conservatory_throws_hullabaloo_fundraiser.php|date=March 2007|title=Flea's Circus: Silverlake Music Conservatory Throws Hullabaloo Fundraiser|publisher=LAist|accessdate=2008-01-26|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071008063644/http://www.laist.com/2007/05/02/fleas_circus_silverlake_music_conservatory_throws_hullabaloo_fundraiser.php|archivedate=8 October 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In September 2005, the Chili Peppers performed "Under the Bridge" at the [[ReAct Now: Music & Relief]] benefit which was held to raise money for victims of [[Hurricane Katrina]]. $30 million was raised during the live event which was broadcast across the world on various television networks and online.
In October 2008, Flea (along with his daughter Sunny Bebop) appeared in a [[Vote for Change]] ad voicing his support for [[Barack Obama]] for president of the United States in the upcoming election.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iOW_-8zJ2fI |title=Flea of The Red Hot Chili Peppers and Vote for Change |publisher=YouTube |date=2008-10-26 |accessdate=2018-06-19}}</ref>
On 20 March 2011, Flea ran the [[LA Marathon]] to raise money for the Silverlake Conservatory of Music through [[Crowdrise]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crowdrise.com/flea |title=Flea 's Charitable Life on Crowdrise |publisher=Crowdrise.com |date=4 August 2010 |accessdate=2011-05-28}}</ref> Flea was also featured in ''[[Runner's World]]'' magazine discussing his preparation for the race.<ref>{{cite news|last=Savin|first=Monique|title=Flea Rocks LA Marathon|url=http://www.runnersworld.com/article/1,7120,s6-243-544--13896-0,00.html|accessdate=20 November 2011|newspaper=[[Runner's World]]|date=15 March 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110826083244/http://www.runnersworld.com/article/1,7120,s6-243-544--13896-0,00.html|archive-date=26 August 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The Chili Peppers performed a free concert in downtown [[Cleveland, Ohio]] on 15 April 2012, in support of President [[Barack Obama]]'s re-election campaign.
On 11 May 2013, the Chili Peppers performed a special concert in [[Portland, Oregon]] for the [[Dalai Lama]] as part of the Dalai Lama Environmental Summit. According to the press release, "The musical element of this event is intended to be a display of joyful celebration and an inspiration to future generations to care for our planet. The Red Hot Chili Peppers have been great supporters of the Tibetan cause, of His Holiness the Dalai Lama, and of the need to work to protect and preserve our environment."
On 19 August 2014, Flea posted a video to his Twitter page where he accepted the [[Ice Bucket Challenge]]. Chad Smith did the honors of pouring a trash can of ice water onto Flea.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mwRIyJLI2X8 |title=YouTube |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=2018-06-19}}</ref>
In May 2015, Flea reached out to fans to help donate to the [[Special Olympics]]. Two lucky fans will be selected to be flown out to meet Flea for private bass lessons. Other prizes such an exclusive T-shirts, personalized video from Flea, tickets to a Red Hot Chili Peppers concert and various autographed items by Flea are available.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.prizeo.com/prizes/flea/music-lesson/default| work=Prizeo.com| title=Win a Bass lesson with Flea and Support Special Olympics| date=20 May 2015}}</ref>
Flea took to his [[Facebook]] page in anger speaking out about 19 May [[Santa Barbara, California|Santa Barbara]] oil spill that pumped 100,000 gallons of crude oil into the [[Pacific Ocean]]. Flea was at the beach with his young daughter when she stepped in a tar ball. Flea wrote "Dear plains all American pipeline, my daughter just dared step on the beach for a few minutes where we live about 75 miles from the Santa Barbara oil spill you caused. She got your oil shit product all over her feet." Flea stated he can no longer surf there or take his daughter to the beach further saying "Some kid in the hood who made a mistake selling drugs will go to jail and have his life ruined but you, you evil lying scumbags will get away with a paltry fine that means nothing to you. You could have had a shut off valve but you saved cash there too. You are the worst kind of human beings, I am infuriated you disgust me."<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/news/flea-plains-all-americans-oil-s--t-product-spoiled-beach-trip-20150609| work=Rolling Stone| title=Flea: Plains All American's 'Oil S--t Product' Spoiled Beach Trip| date=9 June 2015}}</ref>
Flea has been very outspoken towards guns and gun violence, sometimes speaking about it during Chili Peppers shows. He often expresses his anger on his Twitter page. In 2013, he said "why anyone would ever want to own an automatic weapon I will never ever understand. it's a pathetic useless concept for sick people. Automatic, semi automatic, I don't care. I'm against em........ Melt em all down turn em into sculptures there is no need for them on earth. In many countries, the cops have no guns and they do perfectly fine. No civilians should be allowed to have guns. none. and I don't think the cops should have guns either. change the [[United States Constitution|constitution]]".<ref>{{cite web |author= Jennifer Cruz |url= http://www.guns.com/2013/07/25/chili-peppers-bassist-flea-not-a-fan-of-guns-change-the-constitution-and-melt-them-down-he-says/ |title=Red Hot Chili Peppers' bassist Flea not a fan of guns; ‘Change the Constitution’ and ‘Melt them down’ he says |publisher=Guns.com |date= |accessdate=2018-06-19}}</ref> Following the racially motivated [[Charleston church shooting]] in June 2015, Flea again voiced his anger towards gun violence saying "You are kidding me. This is too much. Humans are an over rated species. Sick. God help us." and "The USA land where any sick madman can easily get a gun. disgusting, deplorable, unbelievable."<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.kshe95.com/news/real-rock-news/red-hot-chili-peppers-bassist-flea-reacts-charleston-shootings |title=Archived copy |access-date=17 October 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151118010827/http://www.kshe95.com/news/real-rock-news/red-hot-chili-peppers-bassist-flea-reacts-charleston-shootings |archive-date=18 November 2015 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In August 2015, Flea added an [[apiary]] in his backyard which includes three beehives with approximately 60,000 bees each and over 200,000 bees total in his backyard in efforts to restore the honeybee population.<ref>http://www.tmz.com/2015/08/16/flea-red-hot-chili-peppers-beekeeper/</ref> Flea commented on his new obsession with beekeeping by saying "Deep to the hive super organism. I love my bees. Flea’s bees."<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/fleas-bees-chili-peppers-bassist-starts-apiary-20150816| work=Rolling Stone| title=Flea's Bees: Chili Peppers Bassist Starts Apiary| date=16 August 2015}}</ref>
Flea took part in the ''Pathways to Paris'' concert in December 2015. The all-star event aimed to raise awareness about the urgency of climate action and coincides with the [[UN Climate Change Conference]] in Paris.
On 18 September 2015, Flea and his Chili Peppers bandmates were among over 120 entertainers and celebrities to announce that they would be voting for [[Bernie Sanders]] in the 2016 election for [[President of the United States]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.politicususa.com/2015/09/18/ferrell-red-hot-chili-peppers-endorse-bernie-sanders-president.html |title=Will Ferrell And The Red Hot Chili Peppers Endorse Bernie Sanders For President |date=18 September 2015 |work=Politics USA |accessdate=18 September 2015}}</ref>
The Chili Peppers performed at a fundraiser on behalf the non-profit San Diego Foundation on 27 September 2015. All money was donated to ARTS — A Reason To Survive, Heartbeat Music Academy, San Diego Young Artists Music Academy, and the Silverlake Conservatory of Music
Flea along with bandmate Anthony Kiedis hosted an annual benefit for the Silverlake Conservatory of Music on 17 October 2015. The event, which cost $2,500 and was limited to 300 tickets also included dinner and a silent auction. The Chili Peppers performed a rare acoustic set and [[John Legend]] headlined the event.
In February 2016, the Chili Peppers performed at a "Feel the Bern" fundraiser in support of presidential candidate Bernie Sanders. Flea said, "Bernie Sanders is the only remotely reasonable candidate for President of the United States." <ref>{{cite web|last=Reed |first=Ryan |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/red-hot-chili-peppers-headlining-bernie-sanders-fundraiser-concert-20160127#ixzz3yYh5UbVG |title=Red Hot Chili Peppers Headlining Bernie Sanders Fundraiser Concert |publisher=Rolling Stone |date=2016-01-27 |accessdate=2018-06-19}}</ref>
In August 2016, Flea paid a visit to see [[Koko the gorilla]] and to also raise awareness for ''The Gorilla Foundation''. The foundation said of Flea's visit "One of Koko's favorite musicians, Flea from the Red Hot Chili Peppers came to visit. Koko was thrilled by the mellow sounds and a jamming session followed with Koko strumming on Flea's bass!"<ref>http://www.people.com/article/flea-meets-plays-guitar-koko-gorilla</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.koko.org/node/2226 |title=Koko ROCKS a Flea Bass |publisher=koko.org |date= |accessdate=2018-06-19}}</ref>
===''Acid for the Children: A Memoir''=== In April 2014, Flea started writing his own book, his memoirs. The book will chronicle Flea's unconventional childhood (including his move from a "normal" life in the New York suburbs to a "bohemian" lifestyle in Los Angeles with his jazz-playing stepfather), his adventures in the L.A. streets, his "sometimes complex friendship and collaboration" with Chili Peppers co-founder Anthony Kiedis and the overall "tumultuous creative journey" of the band, which formed in 1983.<ref>{{cite web|title=Chili Peppers' Flea Writing His Memoirs|url=https://ew.com/books/2018/09/11/flea-memoir-excerpt-acid-for-the-children/|publisher=The Hollywood Reporter|date=April 2, 2018|accessdate=September 29, 2018}}</ref>
In February 2018, it was announced that Flea's long-awaited book, ''[[Acid for the Children: A Memoir]]'', would be released on September 25, 2018 however a few months later the release date was pushed back to November 27, 2018.<ref>{{cite web|author=Your name here |url=https://www.amazon.com/Acid-Children-Memoir-Flea/dp/1455530530/ref=sr_1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1519848660&sr=8-3&keywords=acid+for+the+children |title=Acid for the Children: A Memoir: Flea: 9781455530533: Amazon.com: Books |publisher=Amazon.com |date= |accessdate=2018-06-19}}</ref> On September 27, 2018, Flea announced on Twitter that his book has been postponed until 2019 saying "Dear everybody, Due to some scheduling conflicts, the release of my memoir has been delayed until next year. Will have a date as soon as possible. Sorry about any inconveniences.sincerely, flea.<ref>https://twitter.com/flea333/status/1045378033438216193</ref>
Flea also confirmed that unlike previously mentioned four years earlier, the book would not detail his years with the Red Hot Chili Peppers and focus on his life before the band. “It’s my great hope that it could be a book that could live beyond being a celebrity book or a rock star book and just stand on its own as a piece of literature,” Flea says of Acid for the Children, which he describes not as a memoir, but as an origin story: “It ends where The Red Hot Chili Peppers begins.”<ref>{{cite web|title=Read an exclusive excerpt from Flea's upcoming book, Acid for the Children|url=https://ew.com/books/2018/09/11/flea-memoir-excerpt-acid-for-the-children/|publisher=Entertainment Weekly|date=September 11, 2018|accessdate=September 11, 2018}}</ref>
==Instruments and sound== [[File:FleaOxygen06.jpg|thumb|Flea performing with the Red Hot Chili Peppers at the 2006 [[Oxegen]] festival, using his [[Modulus Guitars|Modulus]] guitar]]
===Bass guitars=== Flea has employed a wide variety of basses over his career with some varying exclusivity, such as Music Man, Modulus, his own brand Fleabass, and Fender Jazz and Precisions.<ref>{{cite web|title=Flea's Equipment Board|url=http://equipboard.com/pros/flea|accessdate=19 April 2016}}</ref>
Currently, his main stage bass is a [[Fender Custom Shop|Custom Shop]] [[Fender Jazz Bass]], modified with a [[Modulus Guitars|Modulus]] Lane Poor pickup.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rig Rundown: Red Hot Chili Peppers|url=http://www.premierguitar.com/articles/25290-rig-rundown-red-hot-chili-peppers-2017|accessdate=4 February 2017}}</ref>
According to the Flea Bass Rig <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://whichbass.co.uk/Flea-Equipment-List|title=Flea's Bass Rig - "Know Your Bass Player" (1/2) {{!}} Which Bass|last=|first=|date=2017-06-01|work=Which Bass|access-date=2018-02-11|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180212005130/http://whichbass.co.uk/Flea%2DEquipment%2DList|archive-date=2018-02-12|dead-url=yes|language=en-GB}}</ref> video he used the following over the years in order of appearance. * Musicman Cutlass 1 (No longer in production) * Fender Precision (In black seen live in 1989) * Kramer Spector NS2-JA (Seen in "Fight Like A Brave") * Spector NS-2 (Seen in "Taste The Pain) * Delray Tiesco NB-4 (Used in video for "Higher Ground", not used to record) * Wal Mk 2 (Seen in "Suck My Kiss") * Musicman Stingray 4 (Seen in "Aeroplane") * Musicman Stingray 5 string (Seen in "Under The Bridge") * Alembic Epic (Seen in "My Friends") * Modulus signature basses (see below) * 1961 Fender Jazz (Pre CBS) * FleaBass (Fleas' own brand of bass)
==== Signature Modulus Flea Bass ====
Flea toured the Californication record with his signature Modulus Flea basses (Later renamed Modulus Funk Unlimited after the endorsement). He was seen with several designs over this time. * Blue Sparkle * Silver Sparkle (4 and 5 string versions) * Aboriginal pattern * Sunburst * Black (Lakers style FLEA font in fingerboard) * Circle Jerk Punk-Rock
==== FleaBass (Multi-Coloured Deluxe Spin Bass Guitars) ====
In 2009, Flea founded The [[Fleabass|FleaBass]] company with the goal to create quality budget basses for beginners. Whilst Flea did not perform with his own FleaBass production model he did however use a custom model created by UK artist [[Damien Hirst]].<blockquote>"Damien actually made me a bass, a butterfly bass, it’s a beautiful thing. "It’s not just a piece of art to hang on a wall. The whole new album I play on it. This bass is kind of heavy for live — I don’t play Fenders that much live — but it’s beautiful".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.artlyst.com/news/damien-hirst-designs-spin-guitar-for-music-charity/|title=Damien Hirst Designs Spin Guitar For Music Charity - Artlyst|work=Artlyst|access-date=2018-02-11|language=en-GB}}</ref></blockquote>The custom FleaBass was built with Lane Poor active pickups, Graphite neck and 18 volt Aguliar OBP-1 preamp.
Seen in the music videos for "The Getaway" album.
50 of these basses were made and put on auction for Fleas' school of music, The [[Silverlake Conservatory of Music]] with a typical auction price £50,000.
==== Fender Custom Shop ====
From "[[The Getaway (Red Hot Chili Peppers album)|The Getaway]]" world tour beginning June 2016. Flea was back on the road with three Custom Shop Fender Jazz basses. * Silver Jazz (Sticker of the Helmets on the body) * Road worn pink Jazz * Lakers Jazz (Purple with Lakers decal on the body) These basses have a Jazz style body, Lane Poor Legacy pickup, 18 volt Aguliar OBP-1 preamp and a graphite reinforced neck created by Fenders Jason Smith. The Silver Jazz is Fleas' current #1 main tour bass, replacing his Modulus basses in the process.
===Recording Basses=== * Red Hot Chili Peppers: Musicman Cutlass 1 * Freaky Styley: Musicman Cutlass 1 * Uplift Mofo Party Plan: Spector NS2-JA * Mother's Milk: Spector NS2 * Blood Sugar Sex Magik: Wal MK2, Musicman Stingray 5: Under the Bridge * One Hot Minute: Alembic Epic, Musicman Stingray: Aeroplane, Sigma Acoustic: Pea * Californication: Modulus Fleabass (now Funk Unlimited), Taylor Acoustic: Road Trippin * By The Way: Modulus Fleabass (now Funk Unlimited) * Stadium Arcadium: '61 Fender Jazz Bass, Modulus Fleabass (now Funk Unlimited): Storm in a Teacup, Death of a Martian * I'm With You: '61 Fender Jazz Bass, (MAYBE) Modulus Funk Unlimited (Songs unknown) * The Getaway: '61 Fender Jazz Bass
Some of the songs mentioned to have been recorded with different basses were determined by ear, by experienced and knowledgeable bassists, as there was no official information.
